instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the models for lung cancer diagnosis, and how far can this metric go?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the NN models for lung cancer diagnosis in the related study was the area under the curve (AUC). AUC is a commonly used metric in machine learning and represents the overall performance of a model in distinguishing between different classes. It measures the ability of the model to correctly classify samples as either malignant or benign.

In terms of assessing the effectiveness of the NN models, AUC provides a comprehensive measure of their discriminatory power. A higher AUC value indicates better performance, with a value of 1 representing a perfect classifier and a value of 0.5 indicating a random classifier.

instruction: How were the artificial neural network (NN) models benchmarked in the related study on lung cancer diagnosis using infrared spectral data?

instruction: Can the use of artificial neural network (NN) models based on infrared spectral data be considered superior to classical machine learning (CML) models in discriminating between malignant and benign lung tumor samples for the purpose of advancing lung cancer diagnosis?
Output: Yes, the use of artificial neural network (NN) models based on infrared spectral data can be considered superior to classical machine learning (CML) models in discriminating between malignant and benign lung tumor samples for the purpose of advancing lung cancer diagnosis. The related study developed five NN models and benchmarked them against CML models. The results showed that all NNs were able to outperform the CML models, with the CNN model performing the best. The CNN model achieved an AUC of 92.28%, ACC of 98.45%, PPV of 96.62%, NPV of 90.50%, SR of 96.01%, and RR of 89.21%. These performance metrics indicate that the NN models based on infrared spectral data have higher accuracy and predictive value compared to CML models, making them superior in discriminating between malignant and benign lung tumor samples for the purpose of advancing lung cancer diagnosis.
